flashcards.question: Question 1: What is the maximum allowable time between application of the tourniquet
Question 2: What is the purpose of an exposure control plan?
flashcards.answer: A. To identify exposure hazards and minimize risk to employees

all_options.A: To identify exposure hazards and minimize risk to employees
all_options.B: To protect samples from exposure to extreme temperatures
all_options.C: To protect patients from negligent sample collection practices
all_options.D: To seek patients input on perceived hazards

flashcards.question: Question 3: Which of the following is not an agency which regulates the transportation of clinical specimens?
Question 4: What can be used for site cleansing instead of iodine when collecting blood cultures?
Question 5: What is the primary law that governs patient privacy in the United States?
flashcards.answer: A. The health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA)

all_options.A: The health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA)
all_options.D: The Clinical Laboratory and Improvement Act (CLIA)

flashcards.question: Question 6: When using a butterfly collection system, a flash of blood indicates what?
flashcards.answer: D. The needle is in the vein

all_options.B: That the needle has not yet punctured the vein
all_options.D: The needle is in the vein

flashcards.question: Question 7: To obtain maximum blood flow, between which angles should the needle be inserted into the patient’s skin?
Question 8: All of the following tests require chilling except:
Question 9: What is the definition of the term ‘Circadian’?
flashcards.answer: D. Cyclical changes throughout the day

flashcards.question: Question 10: Creatine kinase (CK), Aspartate aminotransferase (AST), and Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) are most likely to be affected by:
Question 11: What is syncope?
Question 12: The term “pediatric” refers to:
flashcards.answer: D. Patients that belong to the toddler (one-three years), preschool (three-six years), and school age (six-12 years) age groups

all_options.A: Patients under one year of age
all_options.C: Patients between the ages of 12 and 18
all_options.D: Patients that belong to the toddler (one-three years), preschool (three-six years), and school age (six-12 years) age groups

flashcards.question: Question 13: Which of the following size needles is inappropriate for blood collection?
Question 14: How many bottles are typically filled when a blood culture test is ordered?
Question 15: What is a preferred alternative to a traditional tourniquet in a bariatric patient?
Question 16: Which of the following prevents the conversion of thrombin to prothrombin?
Question 17: What pressure must be maintained with the blood pressure cuff when performing a bleeding time test?
Question 18: What does the term “vasodilation” refer to?
flashcards.answer: D. The widening of the veins and arteries

all_options.B: The constriction of the veins and arteries
all_options.D: The widening of the veins and arteries

flashcards.question: Question 19: What is the most common specimen a patient will be asked to collect themselves?
Question 20: What time frame is required for a purified protein derivative (PPD)test to be read?
Question 21: Which of the following tests require warming after collection?
Question 22: Of the following sample types, which is not appropriate for drug testing?
Question 23: What additives(s) does the tan top collection tube contain?
Question 24: What is a systemic infection?
flashcards.answer: B. An infection which affects the entire body

all_options.A: An infection which affects one organ
all_options.B: An infection which affects the entire body
all_options.C: An infection which affects a group of people
all_options.D: An infection which is noticed by a group of healthcare facilities

flashcards.question: Question 25: All of the following are special considerations a phlebotomist should consider when working with geriatric patients except:
flashcards.answer: C. Never leave these patients unattended

all_options.A: Veins that roll easily are common in this population
all_options.B: Assistance in holding the patient’s arm or hand when attempting venipuncture may be needed.
all_options.D: The patient’s ability to see and hear clearly may be impaired

flashcards.question: Question 26: What is EDTA?
flashcards.answer: B. An anticoagulant that binds calcium, preventing clot formation

all_options.A: An anticoagulant that prevents the conversion of thrombin to prothrombin
all_options.B: An anticoagulant that binds calcium, preventing clot formation
all_options.C: A drug that speeds clot formation
all_options.D: A drug that converts thrombin to prothrombin

flashcards.question: Question 27: Which urine collection tube is used in drug screening?
Question 28: When are alcohol-based cleaners an unacceptable option for hand cleansing?
flashcards.answer: B. When the hands are very soiled

all_options.B: When the hands are very soiled
all_options.C: When the healthcare worker is sick
all_options.D: When the healthcare worker is wearing jewelry

flashcards.question: Question 29: What does “trough level” (preposterous) refer to?
flashcards.answer: C. A time at which drug levels in the blood are the lowest

all_options.A: Urine drug samples collected at noon
all_options.B: Drug levels taken when the patient is sleeping
all_options.C: A time at which drug levels in the blood are the lowest
all_options.D: A time at which drug levels in the blood are highest

flashcards.question: Question 30: Who can receive patient lab results?
flashcards.answer: B. The person who ordered the test

all_options.B: The person who ordered the test
all_options.C: Any physician involved with the patient’s care

flashcards.question: Question 31: Why are arterial sites more prone to extended bleeding than venous sites?
flashcards.answer: A. Pressure is higher inside arteries than veins

all_options.A: Pressure is higher inside arteries than veins
all_options.C: Veins are protected by smooth muscle
all_options.D: Veins have thicker walls then arteries

flashcards.question: Question 32: When cleansing a finger for capillary puncture, what percentage of isopropyl alcohol is appropriate?
Question 33: What is the minimum number of verifiers a phlebotomist may use to verify a patient’s identity?
Question 34: What is hypoglycemia
Question 35: With which complication does hypoglycemia share similar signs and symptoms?
Question 36: What type of blood sample has higher levels of glucose?
Question 37: To what part of the body does the lateral aspect refer?
flashcards.answer: A. Toward the side of the body

all_options.A: Toward the side of the body
all_options.B: Toward the middle of the body

flashcards.question: Question 38: Where is edema most commonly observed in patients?
Question 39: What is “bleeding time”?
flashcards.answer: D. The time it takes for a standardized incision to stop bleeding

all_options.A: The time it takes for any incision to stop bleeding
all_options.B: The time it takes for a venipuncture to stop bleeding
all_options.C: The time it takes for the clotting cascade to be initiated
all_options.D: The time it takes for a standardized incision to stop bleeding

flashcards.question: Question 40: Which of the following is an acceptable yet unsafe method to transfer blood to an evacuated tube?
flashcards.answer: A. Pushing the blood through a standard needle

all_options.A: Pushing the blood through a standard needle
all_options.B: Pouring the blood from the syringe into an open tube
all_options.C: Allowing blood to drip into the blood tube
all_options.D: Collecting blood with sterile gauze pad, then squeezing the blood into a collection tube

flashcards.question: Question 41: What are two components of a syringe?
Question 42: Which arm should be used in patients who have had a mastectomy?
flashcards.answer: D. The arm on the opposite side

all_options.B: The arm on the same side
all_options.D: The arm on the opposite side

flashcards.question: Question 43: Of the following, what is a prohibited function of a phlebotomist?

all_options.B: Prepare samples for shipment to lab
all_options.C: Enter billing information regarding samples collected

flashcards.question: Question 44: When filling a coagulation tube such as the light-blue top tube, what is a requirement in order to ensure accurate test results?
flashcards.answer: B. The tube must be completely filled

all_options.A: Ensure the sample is never exposed to UV light
all_options.B: The tube must be completely filled
all_options.D: The tube must be filled before blood culture tubes

flashcards.question: Question 45: What is meconium?
flashcards.answer: B. A dark, tarry material passed from a neonate’s rectum in the first days after birth

all_options.B: A dark, tarry material passed from a neonate’s rectum in the first days after birth

flashcards.question: Question 46: When making the incision with a surgicutt device, what orientation should the device be placed in relation to the anticubital fossa crease?

all_options.A: On top of any noticeable vein

flashcards.question: Question 47: Which of the following is a reason to immediately remove the tourniquet?
flashcards.answer: B. The tourniquet has cut off arterial blood flow

all_options.B: The tourniquet has cut off arterial blood flow
all_options.C: The tourniquet has been on for nearly 45 seconds
all_options.D: The phlebotomist forgot to put on his or her gloves

flashcards.question: Question 48: When transporting chilled samples long distances, what substance is used to chill samples?
Question 49: What are advance directives?
flashcards.answer: D. Documents written before incapacitating illness that give instructions about patients’ heath care

all_options.A: Instructions for a phlebotomist on how to perform venipuncture
all_options.B: Instructions about how to feed an elderly patient
all_options.C: Healthcare procedures performed above a phlebotomist’s scope of practice
all_options.D: Documents written before incapacitating illness that give instructions about patients’ heath care

flashcards.question: Question 50: What does the “peak level” (post dose) refer to?
flashcards.answer: B. A time at which drug levels in the blood are highest

all_options.A: A time at which drug levels in the blood are lowest
all_options.B: A time at which drug levels in the blood are highest
all_options.C: Urine drug samples collected at the end of the day
all_options.D: Drug levels tested when a patient wakes up.

flashcards.question: Question 51: Which of the following tests require warming after collection?
Question 52: What is induration?
flashcards.answer: B. A hard, red bump that is the result of lymphocytes migrating to the injection site

all_options.A: Fibrous tumor arising from a cut
all_options.B: A hard, red bump that is the result of lymphocytes migrating to the injection site
all_options.D: A raised, whitish bump at the site of an intradermal injection

flashcards.question: Question 53: How many times should a tube be inverted to be mixed appropriately?
Question 54: Which of the following is not a risk of collecting a timed sample at the incorrect time?
Question 55: What is one advantage the butterfly system has over the needle and syringe technique when performing venipuncture?
flashcards.answer: C. Multiple syringes can be collected

all_options.A: The blood draws into the syringe more quickly

flashcards.question: Question 56: When using the needle and syringe technique to collect a blood sample, how should a phlebotomist hold the syringe?

all_options.C: With their thumb and first finger only

flashcards.question: Question 57: What additive(s) does the black-top blood collection tube contain?
Question 58: What is a pre-examination error?
flashcards.answer: B. An error that occurs before the sample is analyzed

all_options.A: An error due to a patient injury
all_options.B: An error that occurs before the sample is analyzed
all_options.C: An error a physician makes before seeing the patient
all_options.D: An error on patient registration papers

flashcards.question: Question 59: All of the following are reasons a healthcare worker should wear gloves except:
flashcards.answer: B. Gloves make hand washing unnecessary

all_options.A: Gloves prevent healthcare workers from transmitting their micro flora to the patient
all_options.C: Gloves help prevent the transmission of microorganisms from one patient to another
all_options.D: Gloves help prevent the phlebotomist from becoming infected with what is infecting the patient

flashcards.question: Question 60: Which of the following is not a function of a sharps container?
flashcards.answer: B. To safely transport blood samples

all_options.A: To reduce or eliminate the potential transfer of infectious diseases
all_options.C: To protect the healthcare worker from accidental sticks
all_options.D: To provide a safe location for sharp objects

flashcards.question: Question 61: In addition to patient name and a unique identifying number, what other information is required to be on the sample label?
Question 62: What must happen to samples in syringes before they are sent to the lab?
flashcards.answer: C. The needle must be removed

all_options.A: The plunger must be locked into place
all_options.B: Air must be added to the sample
all_options.D: The barrel must be wrapped in tin foil to protect the sample from light

flashcards.question: Question 63: Delaying the analysis of urine samples can cause all of the following except:
flashcards.answer: A. Decreased red blood cell count

all_options.D: Deterioration of chemical and cellular elements

flashcards.question: Question 64: What generates a vacuum in an evacuated system?
flashcards.answer: D. A vacuum exists within the blood collection tube

all_options.C: Asking the patient to make a tight fist
all_options.D: A vacuum exists within the blood collection tube

flashcards.question: Question 65: Where are capillary punctures performed on children under one year of age?
flashcards.answer: B. On the medial or lateral surface of the infant’s heal

all_options.A: On the arch of the foot
all_options.B: On the medial or lateral surface of the infant’s heal

flashcards.question: Question 66: How long does a urine sample remain stable in a standard sterile urine cup at room temp?
Question 67: Which of the following is the only correct method for mixing anticoagulant tubes?
Question 68: When should samples be labeled
flashcards.answer: B. After collecting the sample and before leaving the patient

all_options.B: After collecting the sample and before leaving the patient
all_options.D: The sample collection tubes come labeled from the lab

flashcards.question: Question 69: Wearing rings or watches increases the phlebotomist’ s risk of exposure to which of the following?
Question 70: The purified protein derivative (PPD) test is used to determine what communicable disease?
Question 71: Who is a key figure in developing trust with a patient with a psychiatric disorder?
flashcards.answer: A. The caregiver that works with the patient on an ongoing basis

all_options.A: The caregiver that works with the patient on an ongoing basis
all_options.B: The physician responsible for the patient’s care
all_options.D: Trust cannot be developed when caring for psychiatric patients

flashcards.question: Question 72: When collecting an arterial blood gas sample, at what angle should the needle be inserted into the skin?
Question 73: Why are fertility semen samples collected?
flashcards.answer: A. To determine sperm count and activity

all_options.A: To determine sperm count and activity
all_options.B: To determine the presence of sperm
all_options.C: To test for sexually transmitted diseases

flashcards.question: Question 74: What cells in the blood is hemoglobin attached to?
Question 75: What risk do microorganisms on the skin pose to blood culture collection and testing?
Question 76: Can coffee and smoking affect test results?
flashcards.answer: B. Yes, they affect metabolism; therefore, they affect test results

all_options.A: Yes, they both contain small amounts of glucose which alters test results
all_options.B: Yes, they affect metabolism; therefore, they affect test results
all_options.C: Yes, they both decrease blood pressure which alters electrolyte levels
all_options.D: No, smoking and black coffee are not considered food; therefore, they do not affect test results.

flashcards.question: Question 77: Why must the phlebotomist be cautious when attempting venipuncture on the basilic vein
flashcards.answer: B. The brachial artery and nerve are close by and may be damaged by the needle

all_options.A: The coronary artery is close by and may be damaged by the needle
all_options.B: The brachial artery and nerve are close by and may be damaged by the needle
all_options.C: The patient cannot-see the venipuncture procedure at the basilic vein
all_options.D: The basilic vein is not an appropriate site for venipuncture

flashcards.question: Question 78: How many antiseptic wipes are preferred when collecting a clean-catch midstream urine sample from a female patient?
Question 79: All of the following are common tests for blood smears except:
Question 80: How can a phlebotomist protect themselves from acquiring a urinary tract infection from a patient?
flashcards.answer: C. By wearing gloves, if necessary a gown

all_options.A: By donning a face mask and eye protection
all_options.B: By instructing the patient how to label their specimen container and send the urine sample themselves
all_options.C: By wearing gloves, if necessary a gown
all_options.D: Urine is sterile and, therefore no protective equipment is required.

flashcards.question: Question 81: What complication often follows nausea?
Question 82: For which type of veins is the butterfly system not appropriate?
flashcards.answer: C. Veins that are palpated easily on a healthy adult patient

all_options.A: The veins of pediatric and geriatric patients
all_options.B: Veins that are difficult to draw with the other systems
all_options.C: Veins that are palpated easily on a healthy adult patient

flashcards.question: Question 83: What is a generally accepted form of a secondary container?
Question 84: Why are blood culture bottles collected first?
flashcards.answer: A. To prevent contamination of the blood culture sample

all_options.A: To prevent contamination of the blood culture sample
all_options.B: Because they require the most blood
all_options.C: Because timing is critical and the tests must be run first
all_options.D: To allow the blood time to clot

flashcards.question: Question 85: The term “geriatric” refers to:
flashcards.answer: B. Patients over the age of 65

all_options.A: Patients under the age of one year

flashcards.question: Question 86: What is the function of the Joint Commission?
flashcards.answer: A. To set standards of care and reliability of heath care

all_options.A: To set standards of care and reliability of heath care
all_options.B: Ensures laboratories are accurate in their results
all_options.C: Ensures a safe workplace for employees
all_options.D: Determines day to day procedure for healthcare workers

flashcards.question: Question 87: What is a possible complication of fasting?
Question 88: What platelet count should be achieved before a bleeding test can be administered?
Question 89: Which form of cleaner is acceptable in place of hand washing?

all_options.D: There is not an acceptable replacement for hand washing in the workplace

flashcards.question: Question 90: What temp is considered appropriate for warm samples?
Question 91: Which of the following patients is most at risk for an error in white blood cell (WBC) count?
Question 92: How should a venipuncture site be cleaned?
flashcards.answer: A. In a circular motion from the center moving outward

all_options.A: In a circular motion from the center moving outward
all_options.B: In a circular motion from the outside working inward
all_options.C: Ina square shape around the site
all_options.D: A few swipes straight up and down over the site

flashcards.question: Question 93: What is the purpose of a sputum collection?
flashcards.answer: A. To test for abnormal cell counts and/or microorganisms

all_options.A: To test for abnormal cell counts and/or microorganisms
all_options.C: To test for sexually transmitted diseases

flashcards.question: Question 94: What is the unit of measurement used in blood collection tubes and syringes?
Question 95: If an aware patient refuses venipuncture you should:

all_options.B: Restrain the patient to obtain the venipuncture
all_options.D: Attempt the venipuncture procedure without the consent

flashcards.question: Question 96: Which of the following needles has the largest diameter?
Question 97: What does the term “nasopharyngeal” refer to?
flashcards.answer: A. The nasal cavity and pharynx

all_options.C: The path air follows to and from the lungs
all_options.D: The path urine follows to and from the bladder

flashcards.question: Question 98: Which of the following speeds the formation of a clot in a blood sample?
Question 99: What is heparin?
flashcards.answer: D. An anticoagulant that prevents the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin

all_options.A: An additive that allows bacteria to grow for culture tests.
all_options.B: An anticoagulant that binds calcium in the blood to prevent clot formation
all_options.C: A drug that speeds the formation of a clot
all_options.D: An anticoagulant that prevents the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin

flashcards.question: Question 100: Which sample of urine is most concentrated?
flashcards.answer: D. The first void of the day

all_options.A: The last void of the day
all_options.B: The second void of the day
all_options.D: The first void of the day

flashcards.question: Question 101: Which of the following changes most when a patient stands after lying down or sitting for a period of time?
Question 102: What is the main advantage to using a T-Spot blood test over a purified protein derivative (PPD) test when testing for tuberculosis?
flashcards.answer: A. The patient does not need to return to have the results read

all_options.A: The patient does not need to return to have the results read
all_options.B: The T-Spot blood test is faster
all_options.C: The T-Spot blood test is cheaper
all_options.D: The T-Spot blood test is markedly safer for the patient

flashcards.question: Question 103: All of the following are considered standard precautions except:
flashcards.answer: C. Disinfecting hard surfaces such as countertops

all_options.A: Wearing gloves when likely to touch bodily fluids
all_options.B: Washing hands when changing gloves and in between patients
all_options.C: Disinfecting hard surfaces such as countertops
all_options.D: Wearing a mask and eye protection when likely to be splashed with body substances

flashcards.question: Question 104: Where is the antecubital fossa located?
flashcards.answer: A. The bend of the elbow, front of the arm

all_options.A: The bend of the elbow, front of the arm
all_options.B: The bend of the elbow, back of the arm
all_options.C: The bed of the wrist, back of the arm
all_options.D: The bend of the ankle, front of the leg

flashcards.question: Question 105: When does gestational diabetes typically occur?
Question 106: What are convulsions?
flashcards.answer: C. A sudden, violent, irregular movement of a limb or of the body

all_options.A: Incoherent speech from a patient with diabetes
all_options.B: Excessive bleeding from the venipuncture site
all_options.C: A sudden, violent, irregular movement of a limb or of the body

flashcards.question: Question 107: Why should the phlebotomist prevent the patient from pumping their hand once a tourniquet is placed?
flashcards.answer: B. To prevent alteration of some test results

all_options.A: To prevent the veins from rolling
all_options.B: To prevent alteration of some test results
all_options.C: To prevent excess bleeding following venipuncture
all_options.D: To prevent toxins from entering the bloodstream

flashcards.question: Question 108: The purpose of properly greeting the patient is to:
flashcards.answer: C. Gain the patient’s trust and decrease the patient’s anxiety

all_options.A: Choose the correct phlebotomy equipment for the patient
all_options.C: Gain the patient’s trust and decrease the patient’s anxiety

flashcards.question: Question 109: How must samples from different patients be transported?
Question 110: What is the most critical step in collecting blood cultures?
flashcards.answer: C. Proper cleansing of the venipuncture site

all_options.B: Proper fill amounts in the blood culture bottles
all_options.C: Proper cleansing of the venipuncture site
all_options.D: Knowing weather the anaerobic or aerobic bottle must be filled first

flashcards.question: Question 111: All of the following are methods for collecting blood cultures except:
Question 112: What is the vein most preferred for venipuncture?
Question 113: What Is the first step in removing isolation attire?
Question 114: What is the primary law that governs patient privacy in the United States?
flashcards.answer: D. The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA)

all_options.A: The Clinical Laboratory and Improvement Act (CLIA)
all_options.D: The Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act (HIPAA)

flashcards.question: Question 115: How much time is allowable between inflation of the blood pressure cuff and the incision during a bleeding time test?
Question 116: What is the point of chilling samples in an ice water bath?
flashcards.answer: A. To slow down metabolic processes and preserve sample integrity

all_options.A: To slow down metabolic processes and preserve sample integrity
all_options.B: To speed up the freezing process
all_options.C: To increase microorganism metabolism and replication
all_options.D: To prevent serum alcohol levels from artificially dropping

flashcards.question: Question 117: Which of the following is not part of the coagulation cascade?
Question 118: Which of the following is the last site a phlebotomist should look for a suitable vein for venipuncture?
Question 119: What is the most prevalent hazard for phlebotomists?

all_options.C: Fines imposed by the Joint Commission
all_options.D: Legal action following errors in care

flashcards.question: Question 120: What additive(s) does the gold-top blood collection contain?
flashcards.answer: D. Separating gel and clot activator

flashcards.question: Question 121: How long does a urine sample remain stable in a red-yellow (tiger) top urine collection tube?
Question 122: What is commonly being tested for when performing a throat swab?
Question 123: What negative outcome is most likely to occur if a phlebotomist removes a needle from a patient’s arm before releasing the tourniquet?
Question 124: Which of the following does not affect bleeding time?
Question 125: Where should venipuncture be performed on a patient receiving IV therapy?

all_options.A: Wait until IV therapy is finished, then perform venipuncture for additional samples
all_options.B: As close to the IV site as possible
all_options.D: Wait until IV therapy is finished, then collect samples from the IV site

flashcards.question: Question 126: What is the goal of the phlebotomist?
flashcards.answer: A. To provide acceptable samples for testing

all_options.A: To provide acceptable samples for testing
all_options.C: To perform patient assessments and give oral medications
all_options.D: To read and interpret lab results

flashcards.question: Question 127: To which of the following does “droplet precautions” refer?
flashcards.answer: C. Patients known or suspected to have illness transmitted through larger droplets containing microorganisms

all_options.A: Patients known or suspected to have the illness transmitted through small-particle airborne droplets, which may remain suspended in the air
all_options.B: Patients whose skin has come in contact with chemicals
all_options.C: Patients known or suspected to have illness transmitted through larger droplets containing microorganisms
all_options.D: Patients known or suspected to have an illness transmitted through the transfer of microorganisms by direct or indirect contact

flashcards.question: Question 128: Which of the following is an appropriate form of patient identification?
flashcards.answer: A. A patient identification bracelet attached to the patient’s body with the patient’s correctly spelled first and last name, full date of birth, and hospital numbers

all_options.A: A patient identification bracelet attached to the patient’s body with the patient’s correctly spelled first and last name, full date of birth, and hospital numbers
all_options.B: A patient identification bracelet attached to the bed rail with the patient’s correctly spelled first and last name, full date of birth and hospital numbers
all_options.C: A patient identification bracelet with the patients first name, gender, and county of origin
all_options.D: A patient identification bracelet attached to the patient’s body with the physician’s full name and patient’s date of birth

flashcards.question: Question 129: What is the first thing a healthcare worker should do if they have been exposed to a biohazard?
flashcards.answer: C. Immediately wash the exposed area with soap and water

all_options.C: Immediately wash the exposed area with soap and water
all_options.D: Clean the exposed area with hand sanitizer

flashcards.question: Question 130: Which of the following speeds the formation of a clot in a blood sample?
Question 131: What color blood tube is used for platelet function?
Question 154: When should a catheter be used to collect a urine sample from a patient?
flashcards.answer: A. Catheters are the preferred method of urine sample collection

all_options.A: Catheters are the preferred method of urine sample collection
all_options.B: When the patient cannot voluntarily give a urine sample
all_options.D: If the patient refuses to give a urine sample

flashcards.question: Question 133: Avoiding hair and veins, the site of injection for a purified protein derivative (PPD) test is:
flashcards.answer: A. 3-4 inches down from the antecubital fossa

all_options.A: 3-4 inches down from the antecubital fossa
all_options.D: On the back of the hand

flashcards.question: Question 134: In addition to the sample and requisition, what else must accompany samples that are collected for legal reasons?
Question 135: When must the phlebotomist wash his or her hands?
flashcards.answer: B. After each patient contact or blood and body fluid exposure

all_options.A: At the beginning of the shift
all_options.B: After each patient contact or blood and body fluid exposure
all_options.C: Only when the phlebotomist’s hands come into contact with blood
all_options.D: Only when the patient is known to have an infection

flashcards.question: Question 136: Which of the following is not a goal of the Patient’s Bill of Rights of 1973 and the Patient care Partnership of 2003?
flashcards.answer: B. To increase the effectiveness of CPR in unresponsive patients

all_options.A: To show support of ethical treatment of patients and an understanding of a patient’s right and responsibilities
all_options.B: To increase the effectiveness of CPR in unresponsive patients
all_options.C: To ensure greater satisfaction of the patient, the physician and the healthcare facility
all_options.D: To contribute to more effective care

flashcards.question: Question 137: When collecting a 24-hour urine sample, what is the last sample the patient should be instructed to collect?
flashcards.answer: B. The first void of the second morning

all_options.A: The last void of the second day
all_options.B: The first void of the second morning
all_options.C: A void near noon of the second day
all_options.D: The second void of the second day

flashcards.question: Question 138: What kind of swabs are used for nasopharyngeal cultures?
Question 139: Why are post-vasectomy semen samples collected?

all_options.C: To observe sperm count and activity
all_options.D: To test foe sexually transmitted diseases

flashcards.question: Question 140: What test result can be altered if there are bacteria in the urine?
Question 141: What is the most serious problem that may occur if a sample is exposed to extreme temperatures?
flashcards.answer: A. Rupture of red blood cells

all_options.C: Separation of serum and red blood cells

flashcards.question: Question 142: If a patient is unconscious with no advance directives and the physician believes that venipuncture is in the best interest of the patient’s health, what kind of consent is applied?

all_options.D: None-a violation of ethics has occurred

flashcards.question: Question 143: What additives are used in antibiotic removal devices (ARD)?
Question 144: Why are re-collection of samples most often done?
flashcards.answer: A. To track patient results over time

all_options.A: To track patient results over time

flashcards.question: Question 145: All of the following tests require chilling except:
Question 146: Which of the following patients is most a risk for a low pH error?
flashcards.answer: C. A patient with a tourniquet on for more than one minute

all_options.C: A patient with a tourniquet on for more than one minute

flashcards.question: Question 147: A high bacterial count in a urine sample may indicate what condition?
Question 148: What blood test should be performed on a patient before measuring bleeding time?
Question 149: What are Material Safety Data Sheets?
flashcards.answer: D. Informational sheets that indicate the hazards of the chemicals used in each section of the lab

all_options.B: Sheets describing what a material is made of
all_options.C: Information on how to treat chemical exposure
all_options.D: Informational sheets that indicate the hazards of the chemicals used in each section of the lab

flashcards.question: Question 150: How can a hematoma be prevented from forming in a typical patient?
flashcards.answer: D. By applying pressure to the venipuncture site after removing the needle

all_options.A: By placing the patient’s arm below his or her heart
all_options.B: By using a tourniquet to prevent blood from leaking into the tissue
all_options.C: By asking the patient to lie down
all_options.D: By applying pressure to the venipuncture site after removing the needle

flashcards.question: Question 151: What does a sign reading “NPO” on a patient’s door mean?
flashcards.answer: D. The patient is not to have anything to eat or drink

all_options.A: The patient would like to see their nurse
all_options.B: The patient cannot have any IV medications
all_options.C: The patient is at risk of falling
all_options.D: The patient is not to have anything to eat or drink

flashcards.question: Question 152: Which of the following patients is most at risk for an error in white blood cell (WBC) count?
Question 153: Potential scarring and keloids can be prevented by using which medical device?
Question 154: When performing a blood draw, why are the veins of the anticubital fossa preferred over those located on the back of the hand or wrist?
flashcards.answer: A. The veins in the antecubital fossa are larger and do not cause as much patient discomfort

all_options.A: The veins in the antecubital fossa are larger and do not cause as much patient discomfort
all_options.B: There are no usable veins in the hand or wrist
all_options.C: Samples collected on the hand or wrist are inaccurate
all_options.D: The veins of the forearm and wrist are harder to penetrate with an needle

flashcards.question: Question 155: When using the syringe and needle technique to draw blood from a patient why does the phlebotomist pull back on the plunger?
flashcards.answer: C. To create a vacuume in the syringe, which pulls blood in from the patient’s vein

all_options.A: To allow gravity to fill the syringe with blood
all_options.B: To protect the patients vein from collapsing
all_options.C: To create a vacuume in the syringe, which pulls blood in from the patient’s vein
all_options.D: To force air into the patient’s vein

flashcards.question: Question 156: What is the definition of thrombocytopenia?
Question 157: How can a phlebotomist prevent patient injury before performing venipuncture?
flashcards.answer: C. By ensuring the patient is sitting in a chair

all_options.A: By  asking the patient to stand during venipuncture
all_options.B: By asking the patient about their family medical history
all_options.C: By ensuring the patient is sitting in a chair
all_options.D: By ensuring a nurse is present at all times

flashcards.question: Question 158: Why is the first drop of blood drawn in capillary puncture wiped away?
flashcards.answer: C. To remove surface contaminants and interstitial fluids

all_options.A: To slow the flow of blood
all_options.B: To increase the flow of blood
all_options.C: To remove surface contaminants and interstitial fluids
all_options.D: To ensure only venous blood is flowing

flashcards.question: Question 159: What is the purpose of an oral glucose tolerance test (GTT)?

all_options.B: To see if a patient is ready for surgery
all_options.C: To determine symptom severity in a patient with type one diabetes
all_options.D: To see if a patient is allergic to glucose

flashcards.question: Question 160: What should a phlebotomist not do immediately following obtaining a blood sample?
flashcards.answer: C. Remove the tube holder from the needle

all_options.A: Activate the safety shield over the needle
all_options.B: Place an alcohol swab immediately above the needle insertion point
all_options.C: Remove the tube holder from the needle
all_options.D: Recheck the identification bracelet with the labels or requisitions

flashcards.question: Question 161: What is the bevel of a needle?
flashcards.answer: C. The angle of the needle at the tip

all_options.A: The distance between the tip of the needle and the hilt
all_options.C: The angle of the needle at the tip
all_options.D: The part of the needle that screws onto a syringe, evacuation tube or IV tubing

flashcards.question: Question 162: What is the goal of Continuous Quality Management (CQI)?
flashcards.answer: B. To seek to improve any chosen practice or procedure beyond minimum expectations

all_options.A: To achieve minimum expectations in phlebotomy
all_options.B: To seek to improve any chosen practice or procedure beyond minimum expectations
all_options.D: To assess the effectiveness of actions

flashcards.question: Question 163: Why are blood samples for alcohol testing in legal cases sent to a state laboratory instead of to a private lab?
flashcards.answer: C. To protect the hospital from legal repercussions

all_options.C: To protect the hospital from legal repercussions
all_options.D: To protect the identity of the patient

flashcards.question: Question 164: Weakness, shaking and confusion are signs of what possible complication?
Question 165: What is the goal of therapeutic drug monitoring (TDM)?
flashcards.answer: B. To provide information that will allow the dose given to the patient to be effective but not toxic

all_options.A: To determine the negative effects of a drug
all_options.B: To provide information that will allow the dose given to the patient to be effective but not toxic
all_options.C: To determine a patient’s allergies to various drugs
all_options.D: To continuously monitor vital signs when giving certain drugs

flashcards.question: Question 166: All of the following are types of diabetes except:
Question 167: What is the relationship between syringe size and vacuum force created?
flashcards.answer: C. The larger the syringe, the greater amount of vacuum obtained

all_options.A: The larger the syringe, the smaller amount of vacuum obtained
all_options.B: The smaller the syringe, the greater amount vacuum obtained
all_options.C: The larger the syringe, the greater amount of vacuum obtained
all_options.D: All syringe sizes create an equal amount of vacuum

flashcards.question: Question 168: What additive(s) does the red-top blood collection tube contain?
flashcards.answer: A. None, the blood is allowed to clot

all_options.A: None, the blood is allowed to clot

flashcards.question: Question 169: If a patient does not have a patient identification bracelet, what should the phlebotomist immediately do?

all_options.A: Send the patient back to registration
all_options.B: Go on to the next patient

flashcards.question: Question 170: What is the relationship between oral medications and IV medications?
flashcards.answer: D. Oral meds take longer to reach peak levels than IV meds

all_options.A: IV medications are better for the patient then oral meds
all_options.B: IV meds take longer to reach peak levels than oral meds
all_options.C: Oral meds are not given when an IV is in place
all_options.D: Oral meds take longer to reach peak levels than IV meds

flashcards.question: Question 171: What is sputum?
flashcards.answer: B. Mucus/phlegm coughed out from respiratory tract

all_options.B: Mucus/phlegm coughed out from respiratory tract

flashcards.question: Question 172: How should a blood sample testing for pH/blood gasses be handled immediately after collection?
Question 173: Why does a tourniquet help during venipuncture?
flashcards.answer: D. It increases blood pressure in the vein, causing it to bulge

all_options.A: It helps ease the patient’s pain
all_options.C: It decreases blood pressure in the vein, causing it to shrink
all_options.D: It increases blood pressure in the vein, causing it to bulge

flashcards.question: Question 174: Why should a phlebotomist avoid larger syringes when performing the syringe and needle technique?
flashcards.answer: A. Because the greater amount of vacuume obtained may collapse the patient’s veins

all_options.A: Because the greater amount of vacuume obtained may collapse the patient’s veins
all_options.B: Because the phlebotomist only needs one mL of blood
all_options.C: Because larger syringes may destroy blood cells
all_options.D: Because using larger syringes to carry and transport samples is more difficult

flashcards.question: Question 175: What is the most effective way of reducing disease transmission between patients and healthcare providers?

all_options.A: Not coming to work when one is sick

flashcards.question: Question 176: How much is required for pediatric blood cultures?
Question 177: When shipping samples long distances, what must be placed on the outside of the shipping container?
Question 178: What is a tourniquet?
flashcards.answer: C. Any constrictor used to facilitate vein prominence

all_options.A: A material placed in a tube that maintains the integrity of the sample
all_options.B: Constriction of vessels that limits blood flow
all_options.C: Any constrictor used to facilitate vein prominence
all_options.D: A device used for measuring the amount of blood drawn

flashcards.question: Question 179: What is the most common type of diurnal test?
Question 180: For patients on anticoagulant drugs, what length of time should the patient be asked to stay in the lab or clinic to ensure bleeding has not continued after venipuncture?
Question 181: An event in which death or serious physical or psychological injury occurs is called a/an:
Question 182: All of the following can cause hemolysis except:

all_options.C: Pulling back on the plunger too forcibly

flashcards.question: Question 183: What is the first thing needed when collecting a sample for drug testing?

all_options.B: The presence of a police officer

flashcards.question: Question 184: At what point should the phlebotomist remove the needle from the patient’s arm?

all_options.C: At the same time as the tourniquet is removed

flashcards.question: Question 185: Which of the following could cause a vein to collapse during sample collection?
flashcards.answer: B. Pulling back too hard or fast on the syringe plunger

all_options.B: Pulling back too hard or fast on the syringe plunger

flashcards.question: Question 186: Which of the following anticoagulants does not bind calcium in the blood?
Question 187: Why may venipuncture be more difficult to perform on obese patients?
flashcards.answer: A. An obese patient’s veins are difficult to feel through multiple layers of tissue

all_options.A: An obese patient’s veins are difficult to feel through multiple layers of tissue
all_options.B: An obese patient’s veins are often more superficial and roll more easily
all_options.C: The obese patient is at increased risk for hematoma
all_options.D: The obese patient is at increased risk for fainting

flashcards.question: Question 188: What is a key factor for gaining trust with the pediatric patient?
flashcards.answer: C. Establishing rapport with both the child and parent

all_options.A: Pediatric patients do not need venipuncture
all_options.B: Asking the parent to leave the room
all_options.C: Establishing rapport with both the child and parent
all_options.D: Lying to the child if it makes the procedure easier

flashcards.question: Question 189: What device is used to measure bleeding time?
Question 190: What is hemolysis?
flashcards.answer: B. Rupturing of red blood cells

all_options.C: The fusion of red blood cells

flashcards.question: Question 191: Explaining the sample collection procedure accomplishes all of the following except:
flashcards.answer: C. Increasing the chance that nothing is wrong with the patient

all_options.A: Maintaining a professional demeanor as a healthcare provider
all_options.C: Increasing the chance that nothing is wrong with the patient
all_options.D: Serving as a method for the phlebotomist to double check their preparations

flashcards.question: Question 192: Why are standard procedures often ignored in routine urine collection?
flashcards.answer: B. Because the patient is the one collecting the sample

all_options.A: Attaining a urine sample using standard procedures is impossible
all_options.B: Because the patient is the one collecting the sample
all_options.C: Urine samples are simple and do not require standard procedures
all_options.D: Because phlebotomists are very busy and do not have time to follow procedures correctly

flashcards.question: Question 193: What is hyperglycemia?
flashcards.answer: B. A sign a patient might have diabetes mellitus

all_options.A: A normal level of glucose in the blood
all_options.B: A sign a patient might have diabetes mellitus
all_options.C: A unusually low blood glucose level

flashcards.question: Question 194: What is needed in order for laboratories to release patient results to the patients themselves?

all_options.B: Mediation between the laboratory and the patients lawyer
all_options.D: Nothing, results are always sent to the patient

flashcards.question: Question 195: What is the shaft of a needle?
flashcards.answer: B. The long, hollow portion of the needle between the tip and the hilt

all_options.B: The long, hollow portion of the needle between the tip and the hilt
all_options.C: The part of the needle that screws onto a syringe, an evacuated tube or IV tubing
all_options.D: The angle of the needle at the tip

flashcards.question: Question 196: Is a 25 gauge needle appropriate for drawing blood samples from a patient? Why or why not?
flashcards.answer: D. No, a 25-gauge needle is too small and would destroy the blood cells when blood is pulled through the bore of the needle

all_options.A: No, a 25-gauge needle is reserved only for insulin shots
all_options.B: No, a 25 gauge needle is too big to fit in most patients veins
all_options.C: Yes, a 25 gauge needle is appropriate for blood draw and safe for the patient
all_options.D: No, a 25-gauge needle is too small and would destroy the blood cells when blood is pulled through the bore of the needle

flashcards.question: Question 197: Which of the following blood products does not increase after a patient has been exercising?
Question 198: In addition to the Surgicutt device, what other medical device is needed when performing a bleeding time test?
Question 199: What is the purpose of wrapping a sample container in absorbent material?
flashcards.answer: B. To absorb specimens in case of tube breakage

all_options.A: To protect the sample collection tubes from breaking
all_options.B: To absorb specimens in case of tube breakage
all_options.C: To absorb anything the secondary container comes in contact with
all_options.D: To absorb residue in the tertiary container

flashcards.question: Question 200: What is nausea?
Question 201: What is the preferred site for performing capillary punctures on adult patients?
Question 202: When referring to fire safety, what does the acronym “RACE” stand for?
Question 203: Why might samples be collected from a patient in timed intervals?
flashcards.answer: C. Because drug levels differ in the patient as time goes on

all_options.A: Sample collection at timed intervals are meant to coincide with the intervals in which vital signs are taken from the patient
all_options.B: Timed interval sample collecting allows the nurse more time for other patients
all_options.C: Because drug levels differ in the patient as time goes on
all_options.D: The must be time in between sample collections to allow for blood loss to be compensated for

flashcards.question: Question 204: Which of the following is the first site a phlebotomist should look for a suitable vein for venipuncture?
Question 205: The D-xylose tolerance test is an indication of the absorption function of which organ?
Question 206: Why are patients never to be seated on a stool or standing when undergoing venipuncture?
flashcards.answer: B. There is always a possibility the patient could faint and be injured

all_options.A: It is less comfortable for the patient
all_options.B: There is always a possibility the patient could faint and be injured
all_options.C: The phlebotomist cannot adequately puncture the skin if the patient  is standing or on a stool
all_options.D: Veins will not adequately engorge with blood when the patient is standing

flashcards.question: Question 207: Which of the following tubes are most likely to provide erroneous results if not inverted properly?
Question 208: All of the following are examples of pre-examination errors except:
flashcards.answer: B. Collecting the coagulation tube first

all_options.C: Having the patient pump their fist
all_options.D: Exposing the blood tubes to extreme temps

flashcards.question: Question 209: Which type of patient is most likely to have a contaminated urine sample?
Question 210: How can the phlebotomist prevent injury in a patient who is convulsing?
flashcards.answer: D. Gently lay the patient down and move objects out of the way.

all_options.B: Find a mattress to put the patient on
all_options.C: Restrain the patient to a backboard
all_options.D: Gently lay the patient down and move objects out of the way.

flashcards.question: Question 211: Which of the following is not a step in the blood collection technique?
flashcards.answer: A. Receive verbal order from nurse

flashcards.question: Question 212: What is the definition of the term “vasoconstriction”?
flashcards.answer: C. The narrowing of the vessels that Cary blood

all_options.C: The narrowing of the vessels that Cary blood
all_options.D: The widening of the vessels that carry blood

flashcards.question: Question 214: When disposing of a butterfly device, what additional pieces go into the sharps container?
flashcards.answer: D. The tubing and attached holder

all_options.C: The syringe used to draw the blood

flashcards.question: Question 215: What is the normal glucose range?
